For this exercise, it is important to angle your feet outward and bend your knees so that they align directly over your feet. Begin by performing these movements with only half the range of motion, then gradually bend your knees to a 90-degree angle.

Stop at the bottom. After you have built some leg strength, you might start "breaking 90," or deepening your squat beyond a 90-degree knee bend. However, be sure to stop when your thighs make slight contact with your calves. Going beyond this range will place unnecessary stress on your knees.

2201043.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to stay in shape.

Get active. If you must sit at school and/or work, move your legs and body around, but don't continuously move like a pendulum. If possible, get up to find a pencil sharpener. Go outside or take a walk during lunch break and drink some water. If you want to stay in shape but are too busy to go to the gym, you at least need to make yourself stand up and be active. Walk. Park the car on the other side of the parking lot. There are many ways to do these things, and they are not very time-consuming or expensive at all.

When going home or to work, be sure to take the stairs instead of the elevator (if you need to climb high, alternate between stairs and elevator). Buy a standing desk or treadmill desk, or use a fitness ball instead of a desk chair. Go ahead and watch your favorite TV show—but don't just sit there and watch it. Cook, fold clothes, empty the dishwasher, or ride a stationary bike. Do a step routine/step up and down (repeat) for a while.

Do squats while waiting for food to cook. Walk on tiptoe, in a duck walk, or in a half-squat position.

Engage in aerobic exercise. Aerobic exercise is the most effective form of exercise for increasing heart rate. It enhances your body's ability to handle physical exertion, leading to improved health. Aerobic exercise can help you lose weight if that's your goal, but if you want to maintain your physique, such exercise is absolutely necessary.

You can ride a bicycle, which is a great way to exercise and get outdoors.

Try jogging or brisk walking; both are easy and free activities!

Swimming is another excellent method to work out your entire body.

Stay consistent! If you want to maintain your figure, you need to engage in activity at least every other day. You cannot expect results when you are not exercising consistently and frequently. Create a plan and follow it.

Do not try to work out every single day of the week. You should have at least 2 or 3 rest days each week. Give your body time to rest and build muscle! Your rest time is essential.
Seeking Partners! Research indicates that if you have someone else to motivate you and exercise with you, it becomes easier to stay on track.

2201095.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how long I should rest between exercises.

Typically, it is advisable to rest for 1 to 2 days between workouts. Performing the same exercise back-to-back can be quite strenuous for the body. To maximize the benefits of your exercise regimen, ensure that you schedule ample rest days. Experts recommend waiting at least 1 to 2 days between workouts to allow your body time to recover. This way, you can resume exercising with renewed energy.

Just as there is no one-size-fits-all answer to how long you should exercise, there is also no universal rule for how long you should rest. Listen to your body and do what works best for you.

2201004.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:I always struggle with doing pull-ups. Please tell me a method to successfully perform a pull-up.

Engage in back and arm strengthening exercises. Pull-ups consume a significant amount of upper body muscles, so isolating each muscle can make your main workout routine more manageable. Before performing standard pull-up sets, try the following exercises:

Lat Pulldown: Sit in front of the lat pulldown machine, grasp the barbell with a shoulder-width grip, and slowly pull it towards your collarbone. Keep your shoulders back and your torso slightly arched backward. This exercise will strengthen your upper back and latissimus dorsi muscles.

Bicep Curl: Hold dumbbells in both hands, then contract your biceps to move the weight up and down.

Seated Row: Sit in front of a weighted rowing machine and pull the handle towards your waist using slow, even motions. This exercise will strengthen your latissimus dorsi and back.

Prone Reverse Fly: Lie facedown on a bench, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Lift the dumbbells out to the sides and then lower them back down. This exercise is beneficial for your deltoid muscles.

Eat a lean and healthy diet. To help yourself gain large and strong muscles for pull-ups, try maintaining a balanced diet rich in lean protein, nutritious carbohydrates, and healthy fats. Although this dietary shift may initially seem unappealing, you can still enjoy many delicious, nutritious, and muscle-building foods. Some examples include:

Proteins such as lean cuts of chicken breast, beef, and pork, as well as lentils, beans, milk, eggs, and fish.

Good carbohydrates like whole grain cereals, bread, pasta, quinoa, barley, and bulgur wheat.

Healthy fats found in nuts, avocados, olives, tofu, and soy products.

If you are overweight, please engage in aerobic exercise and eat less. Pull-ups are a bodyweight exercise, so the heavier you are, the more difficult they become. If you have a lot of body fat, it is nearly impossible to do pull-ups, regardless of how strong you are. To address this issue, try tracking your calorie intake, eat a little less, and participate in fat-burning aerobic exercises such as running, dancing, and swimming.

Ensure you get a full night's sleep before and after each workout. If you do not receive sufficient rest, you'll find it difficult to build the strength required to perform a large number of pull-ups. Your body needs rest both before and after intense exercise, so try to sleep 7 to 9 hours each night. Exercising before bedtime can make it difficult to fall asleep; therefore, try to exercise at least 3 hours before your normal bedtime.

2201016.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to exercise in front of the computer using a chair.

Exercise your arms with push-ups. Sit at the edge of a chair with your knees bent, keeping them together. Position your arms at your sides, placing your hands on the chair. You can also grip the armrests. Then, press down with your hands to slightly lift yourself. You might even become taller. Release and repeat the push-up motion 30 times. Squeeze your knee and hip muscles together while pressing down with your hands for a challenge.

Use chest compressions to shape your chest muscles. Keep your upper arms parallel to the floor and your lower arms perpendicular to the floor, forming a goalpost shape with your arms. Exercise the chest and arm muscles by pressing your forearms together. Then raise your arms about 1 inch. Return to the starting position and repeat as many times as possible while maintaining proper posture.

Exercise the leg muscles by lifting the toes and heels. Sit upright and work the calf muscles by raising the heels and standing on tiptoes. Then place the heels back on the floor and repeat this exercise 30 times. You can also reverse the motion by lifting the toes off the floor instead of the heels for 30 repetitions. These exercises target and strengthen the muscles of the calves and knees. 

To increase resistance, place a large book on your knees while lifting your toes and heels.

Use leg extensions to target your quadriceps and hamstrings. Sit with your hips on the edge of a chair and your knees bent. Keeping your knees bent, lift one leg. Straighten your leg, hold for a second or two, then return to the starting position. Repeat 15 times on the same leg, then switch to the other leg.

To make the exercise more challenging, extend both legs simultaneously. This also has the added benefit of strengthening your core.

Squeeze your buttocks. Sit up straight and tighten the muscles of your lower back and buttocks. Continue squeezing for 30 seconds, then release for 30 seconds. Repeat as many times as possible or aim for a certain number of times per hour. This can build and shape your buttocks.

Perform sit-ups on the chair. Sit upright, bend your knees, and keep them together. Place your hands behind your head to exercise your core muscles. Lean slightly backward, just brushing against the back of the chair. Hinge your body forward at the hips so that your right elbow touches the outside of your left knee. Return to the starting position, and repeat 20 times, alternating sides.

2201009.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to enhance strength through self-assisted push-ups.

Lower yourself to the ground using both hands. Your next step in progression is to perform "self-assisted" push-ups. These are almost like true one-handed push-ups, but with a slight cheat that allows you to build more strength. First, slowly lower yourself to the ground with both hands. These push-ups are performed at ground level rather than elevated.

Position yourself as if you are about to do a standard two-handed push-up. Similarly, ensure your feet are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.

Extend your assisting arm outward. Use your second arm to stretch upward and sideways, which is the arm that does not support your body. The idea is to allow this free arm to "assist" with the push-up by bearing a small amount of weight, but to rely on it as little as possible. Over time, you will build strength and become less dependent on it. 

You can also place the assisting arm on a slightly elevated surface.

Lower and elevate yourself. As before, slowly lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground and your supporting arms form acute angles. However, be extremely cautious about how low you go and how far your shoulders extend, as there is a risk of injury. Once in position, attempt to explode upwards in a single, fluid motion.

Initially, you may find it difficult to lift yourself. That's okay. Simply shift some weight onto the assisting arm. You might also try widening your foot stance.

Likewise, keep your core muscles engaged throughout the movement to generate body tension and protect your spine. Keep your elbows tucked in (avoid flaring them outward), and draw your shoulder blades down and back.

Alternate attempts with "negative" single-arm push-ups. Another exercise that can enhance strength and perfect form is the "negative" push-up. This involves focusing on the negative or lowering phase. At this point, you are almost performing a true one-arm push-up. 

Use one arm to perform this. Place the unused arm behind your back. 

Start from the initial position and lower yourself to the ground. Move as slowly as possible and maintain control over the movement. 

When you reach the bottom, place the free hand on the ground and push yourself up. Continue with your movement.

Repeat and change stance. Whether you are trying self-assisted or negative one-arm push-ups, be sure to switch it up and use the other arm. You can also alternate arms for each repetition instead of doing an entire set with one arm.

It is important to use both arms to avoid creating muscle imbalances or differences in strength.

2201032.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to get broader shoulders.

Try lateral movements. A great exercise for strengthening the shoulder muscles is the lateral raise. Start with lightweight and gradually progress to heavier weights as your strength increases. 

To perform this exercise, hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms positioned by your sides. Then, raise the dumbbells to shoulder height. 

Perform three sets, with each set consisting of 6 to 10 repetitions.

Perform upright rows with a wide grip. Upright rows are also very suitable for building wider shoulders. By performing upright rows with a wide grip, you can exercise the outer edge muscles of the shoulders, which may more easily widen them.

To perform an upright row, grab the low cable bar. Using an overhand grip, lift and pull the barbell straight up and back, leading with the shoulders and pulling the barbell backward.

Alternatively, you can use dumbbells for rows. Stand beside a bench and place one knee on it. Then, place your hand on the bench on the same side of your body and grab a dumbbell with the other hand. Pull the weight upwards, while lifting your elbow into the air behind you.

Do three sets, repeating 6 to 10 times per set, or do as many as you can until you can no longer maintain proper form.

Try some rear deltoid raises. You can also exercise the rear deltoids to increase shoulder width. These are similar to lateral deltoid raises, but can be performed while bending over.

To perform rear deltoid raises, bend over until your back is parallel to the ground. Hold a light to medium dumbbell in each hand. The weight should not be too heavy, so you can lift it more than a few times.

Then, begin to lift the dumbbells out and away from your body until they are nearly parallel with your back. Repeat for three sets of 8 to 10 repetitions on each side.

Perform a front deltoid raise. The front of your shoulders also has deltoid muscles, and you can work them out by performing front deltoid raises. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 

Begin with your hands close to your body, then lift the dumbbells upward and in front of your body. 

When the dumbbells are approximately at shoulder height, slowly return them to the starting position. 

Repeat 8 to 10 times for 3 sets on each side.

Performed overhead presses. Pressing heavy objects above your head can also help increase the volume of your shoulders and make them appear wider. First, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. To perform the exercise, press the dumbbells straight up above your head, then slowly lower them. Do three sets, with 8 to 10 repetitions per set.

Try wide-grip pull-ups. If you want to work with your own body weight, doing pull-ups is a good option. Pull-ups simultaneously exercise your shoulder muscles as well as your arms and back muscles. Using a wide grip also enhances shoulder engagement.

Position your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, grasping the pull-up bar. Then, pull your body upward until your chin reaches the barbell. Do as many pull-ups as possible.

If you're not yet able to perform regular pull-ups, you can try assisted pull-ups using a machine. Most gyms have one of these machines. They use weights to counterbalance your body weight, making pull-ups a bit easier.

Perform pike push-ups. Push-ups also utilize your body weight to train your upper body and core muscles. However, if you do pike push-ups, you can more intensely target your shoulder muscles.

To perform pike push-ups, you will need a weight bench or a sturdy chair. Get into a push-up position in front of the bench or chair, then place your feet on the chair.

Push your upper body back towards the chair with your hands until you are in a pike position, similar to a handstand but with your feet placed on the bench or chair. Your body should be bent at the waist.

To perform the exercise, bend your arms, bringing your face towards the ground. Then, push yourself back up as you approach the ground.

Repeat this exercise 8 to 10 times, and perform three sets.

Remember, exercises of this kind should be undertaken with caution, as even a momentary loss of grip or posture can cause serious injury to the neck and spine.

2201024.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to perform Nordic walking.

Purchase a set of Nordic walking poles. While you may see some people using regular ski poles for walking, it is important to purchase poles specifically designed for Nordic walking. These poles will have many necessary accessories, such as appropriate hand straps and different attachments at the base of the poles, depending on your terrain. Entry-level sets of these poles cost as low as $70. Purchasing a suitable set of Nordic walking poles will provide you with more freedom and comfort as your exercise routine intensifies and as you begin to vary your walking terrain.

Purchase ski poles that match your height and walking stride. The most important aspect of setting the poles is ensuring that when your elbow is at a 90-degree angle, your new poles touch the ground and feel comfortable as you walk. Some poles are adjustable, while others are not, so take this into account when purchasing.

If your poles are not adjustable, be sure to select suitable ones before leaving the store. If your poles are adjustable, ensure they meet this requirement before leaving the store.

Purchase a cane with a comfortable wrist strap. The wrist strap allows you to release the pole during backstroke without dropping it, and ensures that the pole returns to your hand in the correct position when you bring your arm back. Many professionals believe that being able to release the pole after pushing is important, and this can only be achieved with a wrist strap. Although a wrist strap is not essential for Nordic walking, its use is recommended and should be considered when purchasing a cane.

Decide whether you want to stick to walking on the sidewalk or venture onto a hiking trail. Although many people engage in Nordic walking on sidewalks, you can also take advantage of other terrains. Nordic walking can be done while hiking in mountainous regions or on other muddy trails, serving as a substitute for trekking poles.

If you are walking on the sidewalk, please use the attachable rubber pads that cover the bottom of the poles. These rubber pads should be provided with your Nordic walking poles, so be sure to check that they are included before purchasing.

If you are walking on dirt, use the metal tips at the end of the Nordic walking poles.

Wear regular walking shoes on sidewalks and hiking boots on trails. Depending on the distance you plan to walk and the terrain you will encounter, high-quality walking shoes are very important. If you intend to change the terrain you usually walk on, consider purchasing new, more suitable shoes.

2201011.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to do Hindu push-ups for a full-body workout.

Move downward onto your hands and knees. Place your palms on the floor with fingers spread apart. Align your wrists so they are parallel to each other and directly beneath your shoulders. Position your knees under your hips. Keep your hands aligned with your knees. This is called the tabletop position, which is the simplest way to transition into an inverted V shape or downward-facing dog pose.

Curl your toes under and roll back onto your feet. Lift your knees off the floor and press your hands into the ground. Look down at the floor, keeping your neck and back aligned in a straight line. For beginners, spread your hands and feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. If you are familiar with the downward dog pose, keep your hands and feet together for a more intense workout. When adjusting the posture, keep your knees and elbows bent to maintain stability.

Straighten your knees and elbows to form an inverted V. Support your shoulders, arms, and wrists by lifting your hips toward the ceiling. Lower your heels toward the floor and gaze at your feet. In this position, you will resemble an inverted V.

This is the starting position for the Hindu push-up. After completing each repetition, you will return to this position.

Slightly bend your elbows to move your shoulders away from your ears.

It is alright if you cannot lower your heels all the way to the floor. Many people have tight hamstrings, and this position may help stretch them.

Bend your arms and lower your hips so that your body is parallel to the floor. Inhale as you lower your body. Bend your elbows so that they are close to the sides of your body. Some people place their forearms on the floor as they lower their body. This is fine, but do not let other parts of your body touch the floor. Maintain a straight line with your head, neck, and back.

Extend your arms, lift your head and chest. Avoid letting your body touch the ground, and push your head and chest forward. As you gracefully move your head and chest in a C-shaped motion, exhale through your mouth, feeling as if you are diving under a bar. After scooping up your head with a diving and surfacing motion, straighten your arms, lift your torso, and look upwards. 

This posture is very similar to the upward dog pose in yoga, but you should not adjust your feet to allow your toes to touch the floor. Remember to take a deep breath through your nose before starting this movement.

Raise your hips to return to the V position. Use your abdominal muscles and gluteus maximus, that is, your gluteal muscles, to lift your back into the air. [11] Inhale deeply through your nose as you push back to the starting position. When you reach the V position, exhale through your mouth. 

To return to the starting position, you do not need to reverse using a sweeping or dipping motion. Simply push your hips back into an inverted V shape. 

At this point, you have completed one Hindu push-up. Use smooth movements to execute each step.

Focus on using proper form. When starting a new fitness program, it is best to take it slow. If you are a beginner, it is recommended to do as many push-ups or repetitions as possible while maintaining good posture. For instance, doing 3 or 5 repetitions is sufficient.

As you progress, increase the repetitions and add more sets. For example, perform 2 sets of 3 repetitions or push-ups.

If you are more advanced, perform more sets and repetitions. For instance, 3 sets with 8 to 10 push-ups or repetitions.

Perform Hindu push-ups with a sweeping motion seamlessly, with no delay between each part.

2201060.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me which set of resistance bands I should purchase.

If you want versatility, purchase a standard large Loop Band. The vast majority of resistance bands are large loop bands. They are closed loops without handles and offer you the most options in terms of available exercises. They come in various lengths, but if necessary, you can always wrap them multiple times around your anchor or feet to artificially shorten them.

If you know you don't need a lot of resistance or if you are buying bands for physical therapy exercises at home, purchase therapeutic bands. They are the same as Loop Bands, but these sets typically have lighter resistance.

If you find that space is a bit limited, please consider purchasing mini resistance bands. Mini bands have the same frequency as larger bands, but they are much smaller and have compressed resistance. In other words, both the lightweight large bands and the lightweight mini bands will provide the same level of resistance, without requiring you to stretch the bands extensively. This makes them an ideal choice for home workouts in confined spaces.

With mini resistance bands, you may not be able to do many standing exercises where the band wraps around your feet, but you can actually use them for a variety of exercises by wrapping the bands around your ankles, thighs, and wrists, which might be challenging with larger bands.

There are also figure-eight bands available. These typically have handles and are designed for upper-body workouts. While they are not very popular, they are a good option if you want to do a small amount of chest and arm exercises with the bands.

If you want better grip, please purchase straps with handles. If you are looking for resistance bands specifically for upper body exercises and want maximum wrist comfort, please buy a set of resistance bands with handles. These bands are usually a bit more expensive, but they are worth it if you want to keep your hands comfortable during workouts.

Since you can only hold the handles with your hands, you cannot perform any lower body exercises that require wrapping the band around your legs.

2201065.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me if resistance bands can strengthen muscles.

Absolutely; in fact, they may be better than free weights! Free weights remain fixed when you use them because, regardless of the position during your movement, a 20-pound (9.1 kilograms) dumbbell maintains the same weight when in use. The more resistance bands are stretched, the harder they become to use. Therefore, as you expand your range of motion, your muscles endure greater stress. This incrementally increasing resistance is not only safer for your joints but may also enhance your overall gains.

If you are not yet prepared, do not use an extremely high level of resistance merely because you wish to build muscle. As long as your muscles are exhausted by the end of the workout, you can achieve nearly the same level of muscle growth by doing a high number of repetitions!

Ultimately, as your body becomes stronger, you may need to transition to weight training, but resistance bands could be a great way to start your training.

2201051.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to perform weighted push-ups on my own.

Wear a weighted vest to increase the intensity level of your workout. A weighted vest is an excellent investment for a variety of exercises, and it is particularly suitable for individual weighted push-ups. If you are new to weighted push-ups, purchase a vest weighing between 4 to 10 pounds (1.8 to 4.5 kilograms); if you are more experienced and know what weight you can handle, you can buy a vest weighing up to 150 pounds (68 kilograms).

Some vests come with additional weights that you can add as you become stronger. If you plan to increase the weight over time, consider investing in one of these.

A weighted vest concentrates additional load on your shoulders and upper body, which means your lower back should remain safe during the workout.

If your posture is poor or you have not mastered unweighted push-ups, wait before using a weighted vest. If you are not yet a regular push-up expert, it could harm your body.

In addition to benefiting your push-up routine, a weighted vest is also excellent for cardiovascular health. Try wearing it while hiking for an intense, active sweat session.

Use a resistance band to challenge yourself and provide resistance during push-ups. The slender resistance band is easy to secure in place by oneself and won't cause injury to your back or shoulders due to shifting weights. Wrap the hand loop between the index finger and thumb of each hand, allowing it to hook over the palms. Position the band over your shoulders, level with the elbows, then assume the push-up position. Ensure the band is flexible enough so that you can extend your arms as the band passes over the shoulders. As you become stronger, switch to a tighter band for greater resistance. If you are traveling, resistance bands are a great option. They are lightweight, but they can do many things to help you achieve an excellent workout.

Put on a backpack filled with kettlebells to do temporary weighted push-ups. Use a backpack with chest and shoulder straps so that it can be securely fastened to your body. Fill the backpack with the desired weight, then add towels to the empty spaces to prevent the kettlebells from slipping. Ensure the towels firmly secure the backpack to help the kettlebells remain balanced.

This method is excellent if you don't have any special fitness equipment at home. Kettlebells or water bottles can easily adjust the weight you lift. Use kettlebells as the primary weight source and add extra pounds with water bottles if needed.

Make sure to place the backpack on your shoulders to avoid straining your lower back.

Slide the heavy object onto your back, balance it, and assume a push-up position. For this method, use round, flat barbell weights instead of dumbbells or handheld weights. If you cannot lift the weight by hand, choose an alternative method. Kneel on the ground and carefully grasp the weight behind you. As you bend forward, balance it on your shoulders, place one hand on the floor, and cautiously position yourself. Do push-ups while keeping the weight balanced on your shoulders.

After completing the push-ups, place your knees back on the ground, extend one hand upwards to balance the weight, and then carefully lift your chest to grasp the other side of the weight before moving it to the floor.

This option is riskier since you are managing the heavy object by yourself. Typically, you can only perform this option on your own with a single weight. Carrying two or more weights on your back by yourself can be difficult and potentially dangerous.

2201033.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me a way to achieve broader shoulders.

If you are overweight, please lose weight. In contrast, carrying extra weight around the waist will make your shoulders look smaller. In addition to shaping shoulder muscles, try to lose weight to reduce your waistline. This will help create a V-shape effect and make your shoulders appear wider.

To lose weight, you need to reduce your overall caloric intake so that you consume fewer calories than you burn. Try recording everything you eat to determine how many calories you consume and reduce as needed.

Eat more non-starchy vegetables, such as green beans, broccoli, peppers, and zucchini, to help reduce total calorie intake. You can also replace fatty proteins with lean proteins, such as skinless chicken, turkey burgers, tofu, and eggs.

Stand up straight. Good posture can make you look slimmer and also enhance your shoulders. Keep your body erect, chest outward, and shoulders back to make them appear broader. Remind yourself throughout the day to correct your posture, such as by placing a note on your desk or setting an alarm on your phone.

Boost your confidence. Exuding confidence affects the way people perceive you. Confidence also contributes to feeling good about yourself. If your confidence is low, work on building it so you can look and feel your best. 

Try writing a letter to yourself from the perspective of someone who cares about you and wants to enhance your confidence. What might that person say? What positive traits might he/she point out? After writing this letter, try to read it once a day to help strengthen your confidence.

2201050.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to use the stairs for exercise.

If you are able to perform stair sprints, engage in more intense aerobic exercise. It's quite simple: run up the stairs as quickly as possible, walk briskly (or jog) back down, and then run up again. Move upward as fast as you can, for as long as you can—this may only be 1-2 minutes or even less. Stay relaxed during a 1-2 minute rest period, then perform 1 or 2 more sets of sprints.

Running up the stairs really gets your heart racing. Please remember, if you are not ready for such intense exercise, it could be dangerous. Use caution and gradually increase your speed—you don't want to risk a heart attack or injury from falling.

To help maintain your pace, swing your arms back and forth. This will help you keep moving forward and work your body more rigorously.

Avoid taking two steps at a time during stair sprints unless you feel truly comfortable and safe doing so. Additionally, if you have knee issues, please avoid this exercise.

Hop up step-by-step using one or both feet—but be cautious. Jumping up stairs is a plyometric exercise that, as a great aerobic workout, can also get your heart pumping. Start by facing the stairs with both feet on the floor or on the bottom step. Slightly bend your knees and propel yourself off the ground so that you land cleanly and safely. Continue doing this all the way up the stairs.

Jumping stairs is a good workout, but if you have poor balance or are not in good physical condition, there is certainly a risk of slipping and falling.

If your steps are shallow, do not perform this exercise. Your entire foot needs to be able to rest flat on each stair tread, not hanging over the edge.

Some people perform single-leg jumps for a more intense workout, but keep in mind that the risk factor is even higher.

Stair lunges are an excellent exercise for training the strength of the legs and glutes. Begin the lunge at the bottom of the stairs. Step your right foot onto the 2nd or 3rd stair, ensuring you stretch but do not overstrain your leg muscles. Focus on pulling yourself up the stairs with your right leg—if done correctly, you'll really feel your thigh muscles! Lift your left leg so it joins your right foot on the step. Start the next lunge with your left foot and continue alternating. Aim for 10 lunges on each side or as many as you can perform.

Stair lunges may put pressure on your knees. If stepping forward causes knee discomfort, try doing reverse (or backward) lunges when descending the stairs.

Target your inner and outer thighs as a supplement to lunges. First, stand on the bottom step, with your right side facing the stairs. Step sideways with your right leg onto the first step, then bring your left leg up to meet your right leg. Repeat this process until you reach the top of the stairs, then walk back down and do it again, this time leading with your left leg. 

Do not perform this exercise if the depth of the stair tread is not sufficient to accommodate your feet side by side. 

Try alternating between forward lunges, backward lunges, and side lunges. You will definitely feel the burn!

Condition the calves by lifting the toes at the edge of a step. Calf raises indeed make your calves pop by targeting your gastrocnemius muscles. Here's how to perform them:

First, stand at the edge of a bottom step with your feet. The front 1/4 to 1/3 of each foot should be on the step; your heels should hang off the edge.

Rise onto your tiptoes as high as possible. Keep your back, legs, and feet straight, and avoid leaning forward or backward.

Hold the calf raise for 5-10 seconds, then lower and repeat 10-20 times. Rest for 1-2 minutes, and do another set if needed.

If you're concerned about balance, place at least one hand on a railing or handrail.

Try performing this exercise with one leg for a more effective workout, provided you have railings on both sides to support your balance.

Exercise your arms, chest, and core with incline and decline push-ups. Push-ups are an excellent strength training exercise, and using stairs can elevate their effectiveness! Try performing 2-3 sets of 10-20 repetitions of incline and decline push-ups using the following technique:

Face the stairs, placing your hands on the first step (for a greater challenge) or the second step (for an easier push-up). Keep your arms straight without locking your elbows, and extend your legs straight behind you.

While keeping your hands shoulder-width apart, slowly bend your elbows to lower your upper body and face gradually towards the step.

Lower until your nose almost touches the step. Pause in this position for at least one second, then slowly push yourself back to the starting position.

After completing a set of incline push-ups, place your feet on the first or second step and position your hands on the floor to perform a set of decline push-ups.

In a training session, mix and match various stair-based aerobic exercises. Engaging in a stair-based aerobic workout for 10, 20, or even 30 minutes might lead to physical exhaustion or boredom, so don't hesitate to shake things up by creating your own interval training program. The simplest form of interval training includes alternating between medium-speed and maximum-speed step-ups and step-downs, lasting about 1-2 minutes each. However, feel free to compile your own interval training regimen by piecing together a variety of stair-based exercises.

Begin with a 5-minute warm-up, such as slowly walking up and down the stairs, and end with a 5-minute cool down. Also, incorporate 1-2 minute rest breaks throughout the training session.

Here is an example of interval training following a warm-up: jog up the stairs for 5 minutes, sprint for 1 minute, jog for another 5 minutes, and then rest for 2 minutes. You can also add stair jumps and leaps between intervals to truly get your heart racing. Then walk for 1-2 minutes and repeat the program.

Every time spend 5-10 minutes going up and down the stairs. This is no joke—climbing stairs can be a serious workout! While long staircases, such as those in stadiums or office buildings, are ideal for this purpose, your home staircase works just as well. Simply walk or jog up and down the stairs for 5-10 minutes, or as long as you can manage. Take a 5-minute break, doing a bit of walking, stretching, or strength training, then go back to the stairs for another 5-10 minutes. If you’re up for it, you can do it once more.

Walking or jogging up stairs gets your heart pumping and increases your breathing rate, making it a form of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise that health experts recommend you do for at least 150 minutes per week.

Walk briskly up the stairs, taking 2 or more steps with each stride. Stair climbing is an excellent exercise, but you can make it more challenging! Try to extend your stride, safely and comfortably skipping as many steps as possible with each step. Taking larger strides exercises your leg muscles more than regular stair climbing, especially the muscles at the back of your legs.

Walk down the steps normally, then take large strides back up the stairs. If possible, repeat this for about 5-10 minutes, take a short break, then do another 5-10 minutes if you can.

If you have long legs, you might be able to take 4 steps with each stride, but don't be surprised if you fall within the range of 2-3 steps.

In daily life, take the stairs more frequently. Stairs are an excellent form of exercise because they are something you already use often. This means finding small ways to use the stairs more frequently. For example, at home, carry items up or down the stairs multiple times so you can get more exercise—not just because you always forget to bring things with you!

When you are out, find ways to use the stairs more frequently: take the stairs instead of the elevator to the office, or park your car higher up in the parking lot so you have more stairs to climb when leaving.

Exercise is exercise, whether it is structured daily activities or unstructured "lifestyle activities" like taking the stairs. Research shows that lifestyle activities are just as beneficial to your health as aerobic exercise.

2201014.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to perform a basic sit-up.
Bend your knees, and place the soles and heels of your feet flat on the ground.
Place both hands on the opposite shoulders, crossing your arms in front of your chest or behind your head. This provides you with a central point of elevation.
Pull the navel towards the spine and gently tighten the abdominal muscles.

Keep your heels on the ground and toes flat, first slowly and gently lift your head, followed by the shoulder blades. Focus your eyes on your bent knees while gently contracting your abdominal muscles. Lift off the floor until you reach a 90-degree angle, or when your elbows are above or at your knees.

Hold this position for one second. Slowly lower the torso back towards the floor, but try to keep it slightly elevated. This means not resting your back flat on the ground, but maintaining a slight yet relaxed arch.

Repeat steps 3-5 for the remaining part of the exercise. If you are a beginner, just do it two to three times and then gradually increase the number as your strength improves over time. Hopefully, you can also lose weight!

2201048.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me some methods and precautions for exercising at home.

Exercise while cleaning to carve out some fitness time. Life can be hectic, making it difficult to dedicate time specifically for workouts, but you can still stay active every day! Consider all the physical activities you do at home, and try to do some of these at a brisk pace on days when you might not have time to exercise. You can:

- Rake leaves or mow the lawn with a manual push mower
- Mop the floor
- Scrub the bathtub

Walk briskly up the stairs. Try to walk around your neighborhood for 2 or 3 days a week, for as long as possible. Even just a 10-minute walk can really add up! Always take the stairs whenever you see them, or if you live in an apartment building, climb up and down the stairs at the beginning or end of your walk. This is a great strength-enhancing aerobic exercise.

To help you get up and move around, determine when you're most energetic during the day. Try to schedule your walks within this time window so that you are more likely to stick with it.

Compress explosive physical activities into brief rest periods. Think about all the time you spend waiting throughout the day—on phone calls, during commercial breaks, or while listening to radio ads. Remind yourself to stay active during these breaks. You'll be surprised at how much you can accomplish!

For example, do jumping jacks or sit-ups while waiting for commercials, or hold small dumbbells and pump your arms when on a phone call.

When completing household chores, do a stretching exercise. Think about all the times you are simply standing still while doing something at home. Perhaps you are standing in front of the mirror brushing your teeth, standing at the stove cooking, or standing while folding clothes. Come up with stretching exercises you can do while performing these tasks, so you can complete your chores while also getting some exercise.

For example, do a few squats while brushing your teeth or calf raises while cooking.

Use an application to remind you to move. Have you ever experienced realizing at the end of the day that you haven’t been very active? To prevent this, install an application that prompts you to exercise throughout the day. You can usually set the frequency for receiving notifications. Some of these applications also offer workout options, making them more enjoyable.

For instance, a simple application might alert you every few hours, reminding you to stand up and walk around for a few minutes, while others might prompt you to perform basic stretches. For example, you can set your fitness device to alert you every 2 hours, so you can get up and do 5 minutes of aerobic exercise.

Make your errands more active. If you're busy running errands all day, it can be tempting to drive and grab the nearest parking spot. Instead, consider using errands as a way to exercise—if possible, ride a bicycle or walk, or take the bus and walk to different businesses. If you drive, park farther from the store so you can walk more to get in. Skip the elevator or escalator, and take the stairs instead.

Create a garden to exercise while growing healthy food. When you think about fitness, gardening might not be the first thing that comes to mind, but it requires a lot of effort! You can dig, lift, rake, plant, weed, and harvest, which enhances your bones and muscles.

Don't have space at home for a garden? Find out if there are community gardens in your city where you can work.

2201074.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:How to Choose the Right Size Yoga Ball

Measure your height. When you sit on the ball with your feet facing forward, your knees should form a right angle. Stand against a wall without shoes, and place your feet flat on the floor and against the wall. Use a pencil to mark the position where the top of your head reaches. Use a tape measure to accurately measure your height.

Choose a ball suitable for your height. Use your measurements to ensure the yoga ball is the appropriate size. 

If your height is 5 feet (1.5 meters) or shorter (152.4 centimeters), you will need an 18-inch (45-centimeter) ball. 

If your height is between 5 feet (1.5 meters) and 5 feet 7 inches (170 centimeters), try using a 22-inch (55-centimeter) ball.

If your height is between 5 feet 8 inches (173 centimeters) and 6 feet 1 inch (185 centimeters), get a 26-inch (65-centimeter) ball.

If your height is 6 feet 2 inches (1.8 meters) or taller, you will need a 30-inch (75-centimeter) ball.

The size of the exercise ball depends on your height and the exercises you plan to perform with it. 

When doing dumbbell presses on the exercise ball, ensure your feet can firmly touch the ground.
If you have back issues, long legs, or use it for stretching exercises and yoga practices, please choose a larger ball.

If you plan to use it as a replacement for an office chair and your desk height is between 29 to 30 inches (74 to 76 centimeters), please purchase a 26-inch (65-centimeter) ball. Since the ball will compress when you sit on it, choose a ball with a diameter that is 4 inches (10 centimeters) larger than the height of the chair you are replacing.
Pay attention to the pressure of the ball. At its maximum diameter, the yoga ball is very firm. The harder the ball, the more challenging yoga and exercise become.
Try different sizes of yoga balls before making a decision. Sit on the ball and see if your hips and knees are bent at a 90-degree angle, with your thighs parallel to the floor.

2201038.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to start learning to swim.

Put aside your fear. Many people delay learning to swim because they are afraid of drowning. Although drowning can indeed happen, most incidents can be prevented through simple safety measures. Whenever you swim, follow the guidelines below to greatly reduce the risk of drowning:

Do not swim alone. Always swim with another competent swimmer if no other people are around. Areas with lifeguards are typically the best places to swim.

Do not swim in moving water initially. If you are learning to swim in the ocean or rivers, you need to be more aware of the water's movements. If you must learn to swim in such conditions, try to ensure you are with someone who knows what they are doing and be sure to read up on steps for escaping rip currents or fast-flowing rivers (as outlined below).

Use appropriate safety gear until you have sufficient water experience and feel relatively comfortable in the water.

Stay within depths you can manage. When you first learn how to swim, do not venture into water too deep for you to stand in. This way, if any issue arises, you can simply stand up to breathe.

Avoid swimming in severe weather conditions. Swimming in light rain should be fine, but if you see or hear a storm approaching, exit the water immediately. Follow this rule regardless of your swimming ability.

Do not swim in overly cold water. If you are in cold water, paddling with your limbs may suddenly become difficult.

Avoid drinking alcohol before or while swimming. Alcohol impairs judgment, balance, and coordination, which increases the risk of drowning.

Get used to floating. When you are in the water, hold onto the side of the pool or dock and let your legs float behind you—they should lift easily if you allow them. However, for some people, the legs tend to sink to the bottom while the upper body remains afloat. Don't worry; just try the method again. Practice doing this on both your stomach and your back until you get used to having half of your body float.

Once you're ready, try floating on your back or stomach. Stay at a shallow depth so that if it doesn't work, you can simply stand up. When your nose and mouth are in the air and water surrounds your ears, it might feel strange, but you'll get used to it. For additional stability, extend your arms out at right angles to form a "T" shape with your body. The first time you float, you can try taking a deep breath before floating. If your lungs are filled with air, your body will certainly float. Continue doing this until you gain more experience.

Do not panic. Always remember, if you find yourself in depths beyond your control or unable to move your limbs at all—float on your back, and you will have a chance to retreat. If you cannot swim, do not thrash about or begin breathing rapidly; simply lie as flat as possible, let the water support you, and allow yourself to regain your composure.

A good tip for floating on your back is to hold your breath, filling your lungs with air. Another helpful tip is to extend your stomach.

Practice exhaling underwater. While you are still in shallow water, take a deep breath and immerse your face in the water. Slowly exhale through your nose until you feel out of breath, then stand back up. Bubbles should come out. You can also exhale through your mouth, but this usually results in larger bubbles until you finally expel a stream of bubbles.

If you feel uncomfortable exhaling through your nose, you can close your nose or wear a nose clip and exhale through your mouth.

Wearing goggles (optional). Wearing goggles can help you open your eyes more comfortably underwater and may allow you to see more clearly. Look for a pair with spongy circles around the eyes and submerge them in water, so they adhere to your skin. Tighten the strap at the back of your head to ensure the goggles fit snugly.

2201002.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me a correct way to do pull-ups and avoid injury.

Warm up for 5-10 minutes before starting. Warming up can promote blood flow and help prevent injuries. To warm up, perform some cardiovascular exercises such as walking or jogging. You should also do some dynamic stretching exercises, like arm circles or arm swings.

Set your shoulders and arch your back. If pull-ups are difficult for you, it might feel natural to "hunch" your body during the exercise. However, this adds extra strain to your neck and back muscles, making the entire workout more challenging. To avoid this, push your shoulders back and keep your spine arched.

Use the muscles of your back, not just your arms. For those who are not familiar, pull-ups might seem like the ultimate test of arm strength. However, your back muscles are equally, if not more, important. To make your workout easier and more effective, try utilizing the muscles around your back and armpits to help lift yourself up. Specifically, focus on exercising your latissimus dorsi ("lats") and the posterior deltoids ("deltoids").

Cross your legs during exercise. When doing pull-ups, try to cross your legs near the ankles. Although this may seem insignificant, it can reduce some of the strain on your arms and make it easier to maintain proper posture during exercise. 

When crossing your legs, you can either bend your knees or keep them straight. Neither option will affect the overall routine, so choose the one that feels best.

If you are struggling, try performing assisted pull-ups. Assisted pull-ups allow you to execute the same basic movement as regular pull-ups but with a little extra help, enabling you to complete the exercise more easily. Since these are very similar to actual pull-ups, they are great for getting the correct form before attempting the real movement. You can perform assisted pull-ups in the following ways: 
- Use a pull-up machine. 
- Loop a resistance band around the barbell and your feet to support some of your weight. 
- Stand on a bench with one foot. 
- Have a partner hold your feet or legs while exercising.

2201037.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to improve my breaststroke technique.

Ensure that your limbs move together. During the breaststroke, your right arm and left arm should move in sync. The same applies to your legs. If you do not maintain balanced movement and simultaneously move the corresponding limbs, you may drift to one side or the other, and your breaststroke will not be smooth. 

Do not extend your arms too early. After your legs come together at the end of the kicking phase, let yourself glide forward for one or two seconds. Only then should you use your arms to pull.

Regularly visit the gym. The gym is a great place to exercise the legs, arms, shoulders, and neck—these are the key areas you use during breaststroke. Going to the gym offers you many opportunities to engage in weight training exercises, which can help you build muscle, improve physique, and reduce swimming time.

Perform the standing tricep pushdown. Stand in front of a cable machine and place your hands on the top of the bar, spacing them shoulder-width apart. Pull the bar down to the position where your elbows are almost locked, then raise it back to the midline. 

Perform 3 sets of 10-15 push-ups. 

This exercise simulates the final motion of the initial underwater pull.

Perform barbell bicep curls. Grip the barbell with an underhand grip. Position your hands shoulder-width apart. Curl the barbell upwards in an arc towards your chest until it is level with your shoulders. Slowly lower the barbell until your arms are fully extended again.

Start with the barbell without additional weight. Once you have perfected your technique, gradually increase the weight in small increments until performing 10-12 repetitions becomes very challenging for you.

Complete three sets of 10-12 repetitions.

This exercise will improve the latter part of the arm pull during the breaststroke.

Perform some scapular push-ups. Support your body by balancing on your forearms. Keep your spine straight and toes pointing down. Lower your chest, bringing your shoulder blades together. Rotate your shoulders to return to the starting position. 

Do three sets of 10 scapular push-ups. 

This exercise will enhance your shoulder strength, making the arm movements in breaststroke easier.

2201030.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to achieve a sexy bikini body.

Obtain a large quantity of fruits and vegetables. If you wish to lose weight, focusing on fruits and vegetables is an excellent method, as they allow you to consume fewer calories. Pay particular attention to dark leafy greens (kale, spinach), broccoli, beets, berries, apples, and citrus fruits. All of these are rich in vitamins and nutrients.

Women aged 19 to 50 should eat 2 1/2 cups of vegetables daily, while women over 50 should consume 2 cups daily. 

Of course, these vegetables are mostly measured by cups, but there are some exceptions. For example, when eating raw leafy greens, 2 cups count as 1 cup. Additionally, you can count 1 large tomato as a cup, or likewise, 1 large sweet potato. You can also count 2 stalks of celery as 1 cup. However, if you plan to indulge excessively in any category, it's a good idea to choose non-starchy vegetables. Starchy vegetables include carrots, potatoes, peas, and corn.

Women aged 19 to 30 should consume 2 cups of fruit daily, while women over 30 should consume 1 1/2 cups daily. 

Typically, one piece of fruit equals one cup, such as a small apple, a medium-sized grapefruit, a large orange, a large peach, or a large banana. When eating dried fruit, half a cup counts as one cup.

Consume lean protein. Lean meat is low in fat and is an excellent source of protein. Some examples of lean meats include fish, skinless chicken or turkey, beef and pork tenderloin, as well as game meats like venison, rabbit, or elk. However, not all lean proteins come from meat. Other sources of lean protein include beans, tofu, and egg whites.

The United States Department of Agriculture recommends that women aged 19 to 30 consume 5 1/2 ounce-equivalents per day, while women over 30 should consume 5 ounce-equivalents per day.

An ounce-equivalent is defined as 1 ounce of meat, 1 egg, 1/2 ounce of seeds or nuts, 1 tablespoon of nut butter, 1/4 cup of cooked beans, or 1/4 cup of tofu.

Consume a nutritious diet rich in whole grains. Whole grains include grains like whole kernels, oatmeal, quinoa, barley, and farro. They are naturally low in fat and an excellent source of fiber. Try cooking a new whole grain for yourself, topped with some steamed vegetables and some roasted meat; it makes for a nutritious and satisfying meal.

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) recommends that women aged 19 to 50 eat 6 "ounce equivalents" of grains per day, with at least half being whole grains. If you are over 50, the recommendation is 5 ounce equivalents.

An "ounce equivalent" refers to 1 mini bagel, 1 small biscuit, 1 slice of bread or toast, 1/2 cup of cooked oatmeal, cooked brown rice or other grains, or 1 small tortilla.

Focus on healthy fats. You don’t want to eliminate fats entirely from your diet. However, you do want to limit fats and focus on healthy ones. Vegetable oils and fats are generally healthier for you, such as canola oil, olive oil, nuts, avocados, and olives, although oily fish are also relatively healthy.

If you are a woman, you may consume 30 tablespoons of oil within the range of ages 6 to 19, and 30 tablespoons from age 5 and above. If you're trying to lose weight, you might want to reduce it by one or two tablespoons.

Remember, you will obtain some fats from your diet. Fats are found in meats, butter, milk, and other dairy products, as well as in mayonnaise and salad dressings. For example, here is what corresponds to 1 tablespoon of oil: 1 tablespoon of mayonnaise, 2 tablespoons of peanut butter, 1/2 a medium avocado, 2 ounces of Italian dressing, 1 ounce of nuts, and 1 ounce of sunflower seeds.

Skip sugar and alcohol. Both sugar and alcohol add empty calories to your diet, which you don't need. Be cautious when identifying possible sources of sugar in your diet. Corn syrup appears in many common processed foods, so carefully check what you're eating. Drink water instead of juice or soda, as frequently consuming these beverages will reduce a significant amount of sugar from your diet.

Eat less. If you are eating correctly but still not achieving your desired weight, try eating smaller, more frequent meals. By consuming fewer calories, your body will generally begin to lose weight. Be sure to eat enough so as not to feel dizzy or unwell. Do not starve yourself because you think it will get you the figure you are looking for. It is not worth it.

Try using a weight loss calculator to determine how many calories you should consume to lose weight. You input information such as your weight, height, and activity level, along with the goals you wish to achieve, and it will tell you how many calories you should consume daily to reach your goal within a specified period.

Ensure that your daily caloric intake is not less than 1,200 calories, as this may be unhealthy.

2201003.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how I can do more pull-ups in a set.

Change the type of pull-ups you perform. Even the most basic pull-ups have several different variations, and you can switch between them as needed. These different styles engage slightly different muscles, which means you may be better at one than another. Some styles you can try include:

Standard Style: Grip the barbell with an overhand grip, with your hands spaced shoulder-width apart. Then, use slow and steady movements to bring your chest close to the barbell.

Neutral Style: Grab two parallel bars spaced 1 to 2 feet (30 to 61 centimeters) apart, ensuring your palms face each other. Then, pull yourself up until your chest is as close to level with the bars as possible.

Pull-Up Style: Grasp the barbell with an underhand grip, with your hands spaced shoulder-width apart. Then, slowly engage your biceps to bring your chin closer to the barbell.

Add negative pull-ups to your daily activities. Negative pull-ups are essentially the latter half of a full pull-up: start with your chin above the bar, your chest as close to the bar as possible, and then lower yourself as slowly as possible. These are less intense than complete pull-ups, so try to use them as a warm-up exercise to prepare yourself for the real deal. Make sure to start from the "up" position each time.

The goal is to do one more pull-up during each workout session. At the start of each new workout, remember how many pull-ups you did last time and aim to do at least one more this time. Although it may seem impossible to complete when you feel tired and fatigued, push yourself and keep trying until you truly cannot hold onto the bar any longer. 

In addition to your personal workout goals, consider setting a long-term pull-up goal for extra motivation. 

You do not have to measure your success by full pull-ups! If you find yourself struggling, try doing a half or a quarter more pull-up each time.

Engage in pull-up routines 2 to 3 times per week. While altering your form or technique may make the process easier, dedication is the only reliable method to achieve your pull-up goals. The more you practice, the stronger you will become, and ultimately, the more repetitions you will be able to perform. For a balanced and focused pull-up program, try to complete 3 or 4 sets of pull-ups, 2 to 3 times per week.

To allow time for your arms and back muscles to rest, ensure at least one day of rest between pull-up training sessions. If you choose, you can use this time to work on your core or lower body.

2201046.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to exercise at home.

Before each workout, spend 5 to 10 minutes warming up. Engage in progressive aerobic exercises using the same muscles you intend to work out. For example, if you're planning a longer run, start with a slow jog. Not sure what to do? Try jumping jacks, leg or arm circles, or even dancing. Get your blood flowing vigorously. Then, spend a few minutes stretching exercises to reduce the risk of injury during your workout.

Stretching exercises can be as simple as you like. Try bending down to touch your toes, rotating your torso with hands on your hips, or doing lunges.

The goal is to engage in 30 minutes of aerobic exercise or cardiovascular activity 5 to 7 days a week. Aerobic exercise gets your blood flowing and increases your heart rate, which is why it improves cardiovascular health. For beginners, starting with 10 to 30 minutes per session is a good beginning, but you can increase it to a total of 300 minutes per week to truly get fit. 

It is perfectly fine to break up the exercise time into smaller intervals. For example, if you cannot do 30 minutes of aerobic exercise in one session, aim for three 10-minute workouts.

Engage in strength training twice a week to build muscle. Strength training, also known as resistance training, makes you stronger and enhances endurance. Try exercises that work multiple muscle groups, and increase the weight to add resistance. This can help you engage in more intensive workouts each time. Start with some basic strength training exercises, such as squats or push-ups.

Spend 5 to 10 minutes relaxing after each workout. You might be tempted to stop exercising after completing the last set or activity, but take a few minutes to engage in some low-intensity exercise to lower your heart rate. For example, you might switch from running to walking or slow down your cycling pace. Cooling down can prevent muscle cramps and dizziness as your breathing and heart rate return to normal. Gentle relaxation stretches can also improve your range of motion.

Schedule your workouts. Having good intentions for fitness is completely normal, but you might find that the day slips away, or you might forget! Prioritize your health and carve out time in your daily life for exercise so you can genuinely stick to it. 

Creating a schedule can help you plan which workouts to perform each day. For instance, you can do aerobic exercises on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, while engaging in strength training on Tuesday and Thursday.

Set achievable goals by breaking them down into smaller tasks. Saying you want to get fit is one thing, but that means different things to different people. Determine what you specifically intend to accomplish and set it as your goal. It should be specific, realistic, and meaningful. Then, break down each goal into small, actionable steps so that it feels like you are making regular progress.

For example, your goal might be to lift 50 pounds, lose 5 pounds, or run 5 kilometers. If you want to swim 10 laps and can currently swim 4, then swimming 2 more laps within one week is a smaller goal. Then, add an additional 2 laps before the following week, and so on.

If your goal is to lose 10 pounds, smaller steps might include exercising 5 days a week, swimming 2 days a week, and avoiding fast food.

Write down or track your physical activities. Documenting or recording your fitness journey can help you hold yourself accountable and motivate you as the exercises you record begin to increase. You can write down your progress in a notebook or enter it into an application.

Highlight your successes! For example, if you feel more energetic or have lost a few pounds, make sure to take special note of that.

2201057.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to check if my fitness ball is properly inflated.

Measure the final diameter of the ball. Refer to the instructions or packaging that came with your ball and accurately measure how large the ball should be when fully inflated. Use a tape measure to measure the diameter of the ball and ensure it matches what is specified in the instructions. 

If your height is 4 feet 11 inches (1.49 meters) to 5 feet 6 inches (1.67 meters), you should get a 55 cm (1.80 feet) ball.

If your height is 5 feet 7 inches (1.70 meters) to 6 feet 0 inches (1.82 meters), you should get a 65 cm (2.13 feet) ball.

If your height is 6 feet 1 inch (1.85 meters) to 6 feet 6 inches (1.98 meters), you should get a 75 cm (2.46 feet) ball.

Sit on an inflatable exercise ball. When sitting on the ball, your knees should be slightly bent, and your feet should be flat on the floor. Your knees and hips should be level, and your thighs should be parallel to the ground. Check a mirror to see if you are sinking too deeply; in this case, you need to inflate your ball more. If your feet are not flat on the ground or your thighs are slanting downward, your ball is overinflated. In this case, release a little air from your ball.

Slowly bounce up and down on the exercise ball. Conducting a bounce test will indicate whether your exercise ball is properly inflated. Bounce up and down on the ball, ensuring that your hips and shoulders align vertically during the bounce. If the ball can support your weight and your posture remains straight, the ball is correctly filled.

When you exercise on the exercise ball, it will gradually deflate over time. Please remember to maintain adequate air levels as time goes on.

2201069.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to do a basic butterfly sit-up.

Sit on the floor with your feet together. Find a comfortable place to sit and exercise, such as a yoga mat or padded gym floor. Press the soles of your feet together, keeping your knees bent to the sides, resembling the wings of a butterfly.

In traditional sit-ups, your feet typically start on the ground. In butterfly sit-ups, your feet are joined at the soles.

Your heels should be positioned at least one foot (12 inches) in front of your hips.

If you are unable to bring your feet together yet, practice stretching and opening your hips daily to become more flexible. The more flexible you are, the easier the exercise will be.

Place the rolled-up towel behind you to support your back. The butterfly crunch might feel a bit strange initially and could potentially harm your back. Roll up a fitness towel and place it directly behind you so that your lower back is supported during the exercise. Any type of mat is suitable for this, as long as it provides cushioning for your back during the process.

Cross your arms in front of your chest. Place your right hand on your left shoulder and your left hand on your right shoulder, forming an "X" with your arms. Keep your arms in this position throughout the sit-up exercise. This arm position is easier for beginners—this way, you won't have to worry about your arms.

Lean back until your back touches the ground. Pretend that you are doing a regular sit-up, laying yourself back on the floor, preferably on a towel. If you cannot lie completely flat, do not worry—just tilt your torso backward as much as possible.

Tighten the abdominal muscles and sit up to complete a repetition. Lift yourself back to the starting position. Lengthen the spine when sitting up, keeping the lower back slightly curved. Keep your feet together when completing repetitions. Some people prefer to lean forward when completing a repetition, while others do not always keep their back straight.

Perform 2-3 sets, with each set consisting of 10-12 repetitions. Do 10 butterfly sit-ups in each set, allowing 30-40 seconds of rest between each set. If you are a beginner, start with 2 sets and gradually increase to 3 sets.

2201100.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to get rid of flabby arms.

Perform push-ups. Push-ups are a very basic exercise that most people have attempted at some point in their lives. There is a reason this exercise endures—it is effective. Push-ups target the triceps in the arms, though they also strengthen your chest muscles, abdomen, quadriceps, and lower back, making it an excellent overall workout. To perform a basic push-up:

Lie face down on a solid floor with your legs together, supported by your toes and the balls of your feet.  
Place your hands on the floor with palms down, spaced approximately shoulder-width apart.  
Using only the strength of your arms, lift yourself up until your arms are fully extended. Your body should be in a straight line from head to heels. This is both the starting and ending position of a push-up.  
Slowly lower your body to the ground until your elbows form a 90-degree angle. Inhale as you lower yourself.  
Slowly raise yourself back up to the extended arm position while exhaling. You have now completed one repetition.  

Variations: You can modify the basic push-up in several ways. If you are just starting to build arm strength, you can keep your knees on the ground throughout the exercise to make it somewhat easier. You can also try a triangle push-up, where your hands form a triangle beneath your sternum using your index fingers and thumbs.

Perform Bench Dips. Bench dips are another common exercise that help strengthen the triceps while also working the chest muscles and major shoulder muscles. This exercise requires only a workout bench or step, though a kitchen chair can work just as well. To perform the basic bench dip:

Sit upright on the edge of a bench or chair, extend your legs in front of you with your feet planted firmly on the ground.  
Firmly grasp the edge of the bench or chair with your fingers facing downwards. Slowly slide your body off the bench without moving your legs.  
Gradually lower your body towards the floor, keeping your back straight, until your arms form a 90-degree angle.  
Straighten your arms again to push your body back to the original starting position. You have now completed one repetition.  
Variation: To increase the difficulty of bench dips, try placing your feet on a second workout bench or chair.

2201094.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how much exercise I should do each week.

The goal is to engage in 150 minutes of moderate physical activity each week. The CDC recommends that adults perform 150 minutes of moderate exercise per week, with two days of muscle-strengthening activities interspersed. This might look like taking a walk after dinner each night or following an exercise video every other day.

Develop an exercise plan that suits you. Set aside time during the week to move your body in ways you enjoy. Then, make a habit of sticking with it.

Unsure how often you should exercise? Talk to your doctor for personalized advice, especially if you have pre-existing health conditions.

2201020.caption: Please give answers in interleaved images and texts:Please tell me how to do weightlifting exercises while watching TV.

Plan your weights in advance. Each exercise should have its own station. Ensure that each station has a good view of the television; if you stretch your neck to watch TV while exercising, you may get injured. Moreover, if you don't set up your station in advance, you might "forget" to exercise while watching TV!

Be careful not to drop weights while exercising. Consider watching a program with lower intensity so you can focus on holding the dumbbells.

If you drop the dumbbells, do not attempt to catch them. Move your feet and hands away and let them fall to the floor. Otherwise, you might get injured.

Perform a set of lateral raises. This exercise targets your shoulders. Start with a pair of dumbbells that you can easily lift. Stand with your back straight and arms at your sides. Lift the dumbbells, keeping your arms straight, until the dumbbells are level with your shoulders. Slowly lower your arms back to the starting position. Perform 8 to 10 repetitions to complete one set, and aim for two to three sets. As you progress, increase the weight of the dumbbells and the number of sets you perform.

Ensure that you raise and lower the dumbbells with smooth, controlled movements. If you swing your arms, you might injure yourself. 

Before performing lateral raises, do some arm circles to warm up.

Try some overhead presses. The overhead press is an excellent compound exercise that you can perform in front of the TV. To perform an overhead press, position the barbell in front of your chest with your palms facing outward and chest lifted. Then, press the barbell directly overhead. Exhale and return the barbell to the starting position. Do 2-3 sets of 8-10 repetitions each.

Perform some seated bicep curls. If you prefer to exercise while sitting on a chair, this exercise is fantastic! Choose some relatively heavy dumbbells, sit on a chair, and keep your arms extended at your sides. Hold the dumbbells with your palms facing your body. Lift the dumbbells to shoulder level, rotating your wrists so that your palms face your chest. Keep your upper arms close to your body. Complete a set by doing ten of these curls, and try to do two to three sets.

Do not swing your arms while performing this exercise, as it may cause injury. If you are unable to perform it with controlled movements, you might need to use a lighter weight.

As you progress, increase the number of sets you do or the weight of the dumbbells.

Perform some weighted squats. Choose weights that are heavy yet manageable. They should be light enough to pick up easily but challenging to use. Stand in a squat position with knees bent, feet shoulder-width apart, and your back straight. Hold the weights loosely at your sides, arms extended, then lower your body into a squat. Keep your feet flat on the ground, hips positioned over your heels. Engage your leg muscles and bend at the hips to slowly stand up. Repeat this process 8 to 10 times to complete one set and aim to perform 2 to 3 sets.

As you progress, increase the weight of the dumbbells or the number of sets you do. 

If you have joint problems, try doing some regular squats first. Gradually increase the weight when you can perform 20 repetitions.

0801061.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:As shown in the diagram, point P is inside an equilateral triangle △ABC, with ∠APB = 113° and ∠APC = 123°. Prove that segments AP, BP, and CP can form a triangle, and determine the internal angles of the resulting triangle.

Rotate triangle △APB around point A to form △APC; then we obtain △AP'C, which is composed of sides AP, BP, and CP forming a triangle. 

Thus, ∠APP' = 123° - 60° = 63°, ∠AP'P = 113° - 60° = 53°, and ∠PAP' = 180° - 63° - 53° = 64°. 

That means the angles of the triangle are 53°, 63°, and 64°, respectively.

0801076.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:The positions of the bus terminal (Point A) and stations B and C are shown in the diagram. It is known that AC = 6 km, ∠B = 30°, ∠C = 15°. Find the distance from station B to the bus terminal, i.e., the length of AB (leave the result in radical form).

Construct a line segment CD perpendicular to AB at point C, where D is the foot of the perpendicular. 

Given that ∠B = 30° and ∠ACB = 15°,  
Therefore, ∠CAD = 45°.

In the right triangle △ACD, ∠ADC = 90°, ∠CAD = 45°, and AC = 6 km.  
Thus, CD = AD = 3√2 km.

In the right triangle △BCD, ∠CDB = 90° and ∠B = 30°, with CD = 3√2 km.  
Therefore, BD = 3√6 km.

Thus, AB = (3√6 - 3√2) km.

0801071.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:As depicted in the figure, in trapezoid ABCD, AD is parallel to BC, and points E and F are the midpoints of AB and CD, respectively. We refer to line segment EF as the midline of trapezoid ABCD. What is the positional relationship between AD, EF, and BC?

As shown in the figure, connect DE and extend it to intersect with the extension of CB at H.
Since AD is parallel to BC,
Therefore, ∠A = ∠ABH.
Thus, △DAE ≅ △HBE (by ASA),
Consequently, DE = EH and AD = BH.
Since DE = EH and DF = FC,
Therefore, EF is parallel to BC,
Thus, EF is parallel to AD and BC.

0801027.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:Given that in the quadrilateral ABCD, as shown in the figure, AD = BC, and points E and F are the midpoints of AB and CD respectively, the extensions of AD, EF, and BC intersect at points M and N respectively. Prove that ∠AME = ∠BNE.

The solution is as follows:

As shown in the figure, connect AC, take the midpoint H of AC, and connect FH, EH.  
Since DF = CF, and AH = CH,  
therefore, FH is parallel to 1/2 of AD, and FH equals 1/2 of AD.  
Similarly, EH equals 1/2 of BC, and EH is parallel to 1/2 of BC.  
Since AD = BC, it follows that EH = FH.  
Thus, ∠HFE = ∠HEF.  
Since FH is parallel to AM, and EH is parallel to BC,  
it follows that ∠AME = ∠HFE and ∠HEF = ∠BNE.  
Thus, ∠AME = ∠BNE.

0801048.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:As shown in the figure, in the rhombus ABCD, each side has a length of 2 cm, and ∠A equals 120°. Point E is a moving point on side BC, and point P is a moving point on diagonal BD. To minimize the value of PC + PE, what is this minimum value in cm?

∵ Quadrilateral ABCD is a rhombus,  
∴ A and C are symmetric with respect to BD,  
∴ Connect AE and intersect BD at P,  
Then PE + PC = PE + AP = AE,  
When AE is perpendicular to BC, AE achieves its minimum value.  
∵ ∠BAD = 120°,  
∴ ∠ABC = 60°,  
∴ AE = AB · sin 60° = √3 cm.

0801097.caption: Please answer the math problem with image and explainations:In triangle \( \triangle ABC \), as shown in the diagram, \( AB = AC = 10 \).
